titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Llewellyn Jones Papers
titlestmt.author: by Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Llewellyn Jones Papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers that document the professional and personal life of writer and editor Llewellyn Jones.

langmaterial.language: Materials in English, Danish, Finnish and Swedish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from David J. Holmes on the Eugene G. O'Neill Memorial Fund, 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 9: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Llewellyn Jones Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Llewellyn Jones Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Llewellyn Jones (1884-1961)
bioghist.p: Llewellyn Jones was born July 13, 1884 in Castletown in the Isle of Man, Great Britain to John and Katherine Jones. He attended King William's College and the Douglas School of Science. Jones married Susan Warren Wailbus in 1917 and together they had three children: Llewellyn, Cornelia, and George Wilbur. From 1914 to 1932, he was the literary editor of the Chicago Evening Post . During his time as editor, Jones also taught writing as a visiting summer instructor at the University of Chicago in 1924 and 1926; and from 1925 to 1927 he was an instructor of short story writing at Northwestern University. After leaving the Chicago Evening Post , he was editor for Willett, Clark and Company, a Chicago publishing firm. Jones moved to Boston in 1937 to take the position of editor of the Christian Register , but resigned in 1941 due to financial instability and conflict between the Christian Register and the American Unitarian Association.

Jones was a member of the Chicago Literary Club, the Cliff Dwellers of Chicago and PEN, and was President of the Greater Boston American-Scandinavian Forum. He authored books and essays and translated several publications from Danish and Swedish. His books include First Impressions; Essays on Poetry, Criticism, and Prosody (1925); How to Criticize Books (1928); and How to Read Books (1930). Jones was one of thirty-four individuals who signed the 1933 Humanist Manifesto I , written by Roy Wood Sellars and Raymond Bragg. He lived in Cambridge, Massachusetts until his death in 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Llewellyn Jones Papers document his personal and professional life as a writer and editor and span the dates 1902 to 1962. The Papers contain correspondence, writings, and other papers such as financial and business papers, writings of others, and art and music event pamphlets. The bulk of the correspondence regards the Christian Register and the American Unitarian Association, and his involvement in the Chicago literary community; a small portion of the correspondence is personal in nature. The collection also contains documentation of Jones's involvement with the Cliff Dwellers, a Chicago club that supports the fine and performing arts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four series: Correspondence, Writings, Professional Papers, and Other Papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I, Correspondence, is arranged alphabetically by correspondent. A small amount of general, unidentified and third party correspondence is filed at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters to Llewellyn Jones from colleagues and friends. The letters discuss Jones's writings and work as editor of the Chicago Evening Post and the Christian Register , as well as his activities in the Chicago Literary Club and the Greater Boston American-Scandinavian Forum. A small portion of the letters regard his personal life.

There is extensive correspondence with the philosopher and author Warner Fite, whose letters discuss individualism and humanism. Jones's editorial and professorial involvement in the literary world is documented through his correspondence with prominent writers such as Carl Sandburg, Margaret Anderson, Lillian Hellman, Amy Lowell, Edgar Lee Masters, Harriet Monroe, Janet Lewis, and Yvor Winters.

Letters from the Humanist Press Association express support for Jones's position at the Christian Register. Additional correspondence regarding the Christian Register is filed in Series III, Professional Papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged into two subseries: Titled Writings and Untitled Writings. The first is arranged alphabetically by title. The second is arranged alphabetically by subject headings written by Jones at the top of each draft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings, contains untitled and titled writings by Llewellyn Jones. The bulk of the writings are untitled drafts of articles that Jones identified by subject, and that were most likely written for the Chicago Evening Post . Included among the untitled writings is a draft on novels "from 1833 to the present, in which Chicago has been the heroine." Titled writings are primarily undated drafts that include "First Books in a Victorian Boyhood," an autobiographical piece on the books that Jones read as a child.

did.unittitle: "Archibald MacLeish: A Modern Metaphysical," includes draft, typescript, corrected
"First Books in a Victorian Boyhood," draft, typescript, corrected
"Psychoanalysis and Creative Literature," draft, holograph, corrected

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Professional Papers, is organized into two subseries: Christian Register and American Unitarian Association. Each subseries is arranged to reflect the original organization by Jones.

The first subseries consists of Christian Register correspondence, financial and business papers, printed material, and an editorial by Llewellyn Jones documenting his editorship of the paper. Christian Register correspondence includes letters welcoming Jones as editor, article submissions, criticism, and letters discussing the tension between the American Unitarian Association and the Christian Register under Jones's leadership. For example, a letter from Mirium Penny Jacker discusses the tension between Unitarians and conservatism; a letter from Gerald FitzPatrick criticizes Jones's financial judgement; and a letter from Guy Shipler discusses Jones's leaving the paper. Much of the correspondence discusses Frederick Eliot, President of the American Unitarian Association, who became editor following Jones's resignation and shifted control of the Christian Register to the American Unitarian Association. There is also a small amount of third party correspondence. Other letters regarding the Christian Register are found throughout Series I, Correspondence.
In "A Statement by the Editor," a handwritten editorial, Jones discusses the American Unitarian Association.

The second subseries consists of correspondence and printed material regarding American Unitarian Association concerns and activities. Correspondence is from various Unitarian churches, their members, and the American Unitarian Association. The letters include comments on Llewellyn Jones's writings; requests for Jones to speak and write book reviews; meeting proceedings; and expressions of disappointment and solidarity regarding his resignation as editor of the Christian Register . Printed material includes church service programs and bulletins, a clipping, and a photograph postcard of the First Parish Church in Bedford, Mass.

did.unittitle: Budgets, subscription and circulation statements, meeting agenda
"A Statement by the Editor," draft, holograph

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three subseries: Cliff Dwellers Materials, Writings of Others, and Other Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cliff Dwellers Materials includes announcements, correspondence, printed material and newsletters for events and proceedings of the Cliff Dwellers, a club of writers, artists and musicians in Chicago. Announcements include mailings for John Jacob Niles performances, festivals and dances, chamber performances, art exhibitions, and parties.

Other Papers includes a handbill for Llewellyn Jones's lectures, and literary and music materials of interest to Jones. This subseries also includes handbills, a check invoice, brochures, announcements, holiday cards, a review of Jones's "Chicago Triad," clippings, and a photograph.
